frozen shoulder

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed

  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎11-24-2009 09:55 PM

When I had trigger finger, I could feel the tendons in my hands becoming hard like steel rods! I was also developing dupuytren's contracture where the fingers curl up. I know diabetes played a part in that.

Whatever the cause of frozen shoulder, it might be helpful to the OP's case if it could be linked to diabetes for disability purposes.

‎11-24-2009 10:53 PM

lathump2 (11/24/2009)
Diabetes is definitely a risk factor for frozen shoulder, but I have problems with the idea that it is caused by glycated tendons.


Several reference sources that I've read attribute it to autoimmune causes.

Sorta like autoimmune hypothyroidism, but in the connecting tissue.

How many people who take synthroid here blame their thyroid issues on glycation?

Tim.
Report Inappropriate Content

‎11-24-2009 11:04 PM

There is animal evidence linking diabetes and tendon glycation:

http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/journal/118500543/abstract?CRETRY=1&SRETRY=0

That's just one of many articles.

There is no evidence linking thyroiditis and glycation. I was just trying to be helpful to the OP by trying to link it to diabetes for disability reasons.

Re: frozen shoulder

Options

‎05-20-2013 12:32 AM

southbeachgirl wrote:
When I had trigger finger, I could feel the tendons in my hands becoming hard like steel rods! I was also developing dupuytren's contracture where the fingers curl up. I know diabetes played a part in that.

Whatever the cause of frozen shoulder, it might be helpful to the OP's case if it could be linked to diabetes for disability purposes.

Hi!  I have posted before telling of my experience with FS and the solution was surgery.

However,  recently  FS has returned in my right  shoulder, again. Why I do not know after 30 years free of shoulder pain.

 

I had heard about acupuncture as a means to relieve many  external physiical health issues but still wondered about it. After discussion with  my doctor. He said there would be no harm in trying acupuncture so I made an appointment.   Within 3 days I had no more pain.  I continued the acupuncture treatment [not invasive at all] for one month. Today no pain.  I exercise my shoulders regularly now instead of just  occasionally.

 

You might want to think about trying acupuncture?

Always use an acupunctueist who is fully qualified and listed with your state health dept with a license to priactice.

 

Joan. 


* Type 1 Diagnosed for 57years as of Nov 2014
* 50 Year Type 1 Medalist Award from Joslin Diabetes Clinic (Harvard Medical School)
* Medtronic Paradigm Revel 523 insulin pump as of March 11, 2011
* Insulin: Humalog
* Food Allergies: milk, yeast, corn
* Hashimoto's thyroid disease
* A bit of arthritis
* One kidney due to benign Angiomyolipoma.
* Volunteer Community Disaster Co-Coordinator
* Hobbies/Interests: Wildlife Naturalists, artist, gardening, music

Morning injection: 20 Regular Novolin, 32 NPH Novolin

Evening; 30 Units NPH, some R if needed

‎05-20-2013 02:34 AM - edited ‎05-20-2013 02:36 AM

diabetes2112 wrote:

Glad to hear it Joan, that's something I  would consider.

 

Morning injection: 20 Regular Novolin, 32 NPH Novolin
Afternoon; 22 Units Regular Novolin, sliding scale
Evening; 30 Units NPH, some R if needed

HI!  If you are interested in acupuncture treatment --  keep in mind....

* Try to find an M.D. who  specializes in acupuncture and has experience working with diabetics.

*  Or if not an M.D.,  then try a licensed Acupuncture therapist. I have used both and felt comfortable doing so. 

*  The treatment is relaxing; my appts. were for one hour.

 

Whatever you decide hoping you will soon be  without anymore pain.

Joan  


* Type 1 Diagnosed for 57years as of Nov 2014
* 50 Year Type 1 Medalist Award from Joslin Diabetes Clinic (Harvard Medical School)
* Medtronic Paradigm Revel 523 insulin pump as of March 11, 2011
* Insulin: Humalog
* Food Allergies: milk, yeast, corn
* Hashimoto's thyroid disease
* A bit of arthritis
* One kidney due to benign Angiomyolipoma.
* Volunteer Community Disaster Co-Coordinator
